official-title.#text:
To amend the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010 to regulate tax return preparers and refund
			 anticipation payment arrangements, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

committee-name.#tail:
, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Tax Refund Protection Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Regulation of refund anticipation payment instruments and tax return preparers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by
			 adding at the end the following new section:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subtitle B of the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010/st:B
usc/12/5481/etseq

header.#text: Regulation of refund anticipation payment arrangements and tax return preparers

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

text.#text: establish a program to license or certify tax return preparers subject to this section;
regulate such tax return preparers; and

before licensing or certifying a person as a tax return preparer subject to this section, require
			 that the person demonstrate—

necessary qualifications to enable the person to provide to persons valuable service as a tax
			 return preparer; and
competency to perform the functions of a tax return preparer.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall require tax return preparers subject to this section to pay a reasonable fee for
			 licensing or certification under this section.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall, by rule, require tax return preparers subject to this section to provide a
			 disclosure statement to a consumer that shall contain statements—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

text.#text:
identifying the average amount of time in which an individual who files a Federal income tax return
			 electronically can expect to receive a refund by mail, according to
			 information provided by the

describing, in the case of a refund anticipation payment arrangement involving a depository account
			 not controlled by the consumer, the difference in days between the average
			 amount of time by which a consumer receives the tax refund (in whole or in
			 part) from a refund anticipation payment arrangement and the average
			 amount of time by which a consumer who files a Federal income tax return
			 electronically receives the tax refund deposited directly to that
			 consumer’s deposit account by the taxing authority;
that a refund anticipation payment arrangement is not necessary to receive a tax refund; and

that, if a consumer does not receive a tax refund or the amount of the tax refund is less than the
			 amount anticipated under the refund anticipation payment arrangement, the
			 consumer may be responsible for paying any fees and interest associated
			 with a refund anticipation payment arrangement.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue regulations that, to the extent practicable, require tax return preparers
			 that enter into a refund anticipation payment arrangement to comply with
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to the same
			 extent as a creditor making a consumer credit transaction other than under
			 an open end credit plan.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 128 of the Truth in Lending Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Truth in Lending Act/s:128

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may take any enforcement action against a
			 tax return preparer subject to this section who—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau

text.#text: After notice and opportunity for a hearing, the
violates regulations prescribed under this section; or
with intent to defraud, willfully and knowingly misleads or threatens a consumer.
For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ) who is not subject to regulation under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 7701(a)(36) of the Internal Revenue Code of
			 1986
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Internal Revenue Code of 1986/s:7701/ss:a/p:36

term.#tail: means a tax return preparer (as defined in
term.#text: tax return preparer subject to this section

term.#tail:
means an arrangement under which, in exchange for Federal income tax preparation services, a
			 consumer agrees to pay a fee or interest upon receipt of the consumer’s
			 tax refund to a tax return preparer, lender, or other affiliated lender
			 by—

text.#text:
requesting the Federal Government to deposit such tax refund, in whole or in part, directly into a
			 depository account designated by either the consumer or the tax return
			 preparer, lender, or other affiliated lender; or
directly paying the fee or interest to the tax return preparer, lender, or other affiliated lender.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act/s:1029A

quote.#text: For purposes of subparagraphs (A) and (B), a person described in paragraph (1)(A)

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act/s:1027/ss:d/p:2/sp:D

header.#text: Split refunds may include tax return preparer

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Internal Revenue Code of 1986/s:6402

text.#text:
An income tax refund requested on a return of Federal income tax prepared by an income tax preparer
			 may be split between the preparer and the taxpayer in accordance with the
			 split requested by the taxpayer on the return. A split of an individual
			 income tax return under this subsection shall not be treated as
			 disreputable conduct merely because the taxpayer requested such split.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall apply with respect to returns for taxable years ending
			 after the date of the enactment of this Act.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Tax Refund Protection Act of 2014/s:3/ss:a
